entries.title: Westgate SuperBook exec John Murray relishes Super Bowl Sunday
entries.summary: <p>LAS VEGAS — The fourth quarter of -Super Bowl LIII had started. The Patriots and Rams were knotted 3-3, and John Murray, as director of the Westgate SuperBook, had an update to deliver.</p><p>In a VIP booth inside the SuperBook that Sunday, Feb. 3, 2019, the executives of Westgate Resorts awaited.</p><p>Over the previous few days, Murray had informed them that the fewer points the better for the book’s bottom line, regarding side and total bets, and hundreds of props.</p><p>“Eventually, I had to tell all the guys who run this company, in from Florida,” Murray said. “We do want it to be boring, I had told them, but not <i>this</i> boring. Because if nobody scores a TD, we would lose X.”</p><p>According to former SuperBook boss Jay Kornegay, X represented about seven figures on one prop. “No Touchdown” paid 500-to-1 dividends, around 100-1 on other variations.</p><p>Today, Murray admits to feeling some anxiety during that walk and talk.</p><p>“I was nervous,” Murray said. “It was my first Super Bowl as director, too.”</p><p>He finally exhaled with seven minutes left, when Pats tailback Sony Michel scored from two yards out. New England won 13-3.</p><p>“We got to a point where we just wanted someone to score a touchdown,” Murray said. “Those executives were all excited because the game was so boring. They’re thinking, ‘We’re doing great!’ And we did do great on props.</p><p>“That was a little tense, but it was a fun one.”</p><h3>Prestige</h3><p>A year ago, as the newly minted vice president of race and sports, Murray spent his first Super Bowl sitting behind the most prestigious desk of the world’s most eminent decades-old legal sportsbook.</p><p>For the first time in 40 years, Kornegay, having stepped aside to become a SuperBook consultant, did not monitor an NFL title game’s developing liability status behind a book’s counter.</p><p>It became the SuperBook, as the Las Vegas Hilton, under Art Manteris. At Caesars Palace in 1986, he begat the Super Bowl prop craze by offering 20-1 on William “The Refrigerator” Perry scoring a touchdown against the Patriots.</p><p>That got whittled to 2-1 by kickoff. The Fridge, of course, scored to boost the Bears’ lead to 44-3 in Super Bowl XX. Manteris penned his 1991 book, “SuperBookie.”</p><p>In 2004, he took over running the many Station Casino books that ring the valley. -Kornegay left the Imperial Palace and made the SuperBook synonymous with Super Bowl props.</p><p>“Jay raised the bar here,” Murray said.</p><p>Over the last 10 days, patrons have sifted through 50 pages of SuperBook props.</p><p>Murray, 42, is aware of his desk’s prestige, saying, “Many people tell me that this is probably the best office of any sportsbook in this city.”</p><p>Kornegay oversaw promoting Murray from book manager to director to executive director to vice president. Twenty years ago, at that initial interview, Kornegay hired Murray on the spot.</p><p>“John’s very intelligent; that’s a first impression I had,” Kornegay said. “He had a very balanced demeanor and a personality for the position that we were hiring for. Let’s just say, when I hired John, it was a no-doubter.</p><p>“Obviously, 20 years later, we made the right decision.”</p><h3>Putt master</h3><p>Murray grew up in McLean, Virginia, as a hoops fan of Georgetown, his pop’s college. John studied English at West Virginia, but he began betting sports at Gonzaga Prep, alma mater of Bears quarterback Caleb Williams.</p><p>“Just being honest,” Murray said.</p><p>Inspired by Ryan Howard belting home runs by the bushel at spring training in 2006, Murray and three college pals wagered on a 40-1 offshore futures ticket on the third-year Phillies slugger to lead the majors in homers.</p><p>Howard hit 58, beating Red Sox masher David Ortiz’s 54.</p><p>Murray and his buddies had made a deal to barnstorm Vegas with their winnings if it hit. They stayed at Luxor, explored the Strip.</p><p>John had heard of the SuperContest, so they ventured to the SuperBook to watch the Patriots beat the Vikings 31-7 on Oct. 30, 2006.</p><p>“The first time I set foot in this book,” Murray said.</p><p>He’d return after graduating, still holding Howard profit. He planned to get a gig, stay two or three years and have some fun, return to Virginia.</p><p>Murray hasn’t left Vegas.</p><p>“Jay kept promoting me,” he said with a touch of his characteristic dry humor. “I got stuck out here because of him.”</p><p>He lives by the fifth hole of the Las Vegas Country Club — across the street from the SuperBook — where his putting often shines.</p><p>During a round in which Murray sank everything, former UFC champ Aljamain “Funk Master” Sterling called him “Putt Master.”</p><p>Just like Kornegay, Murray will traipse the SuperBook grounds, discussing games and wagers with customers as if he were one of them, which he was not so long ago.</p><h3>He’ll never walk alone</h3><p>When his Gonzaga Prep rugby team toured the British Isles one summer to play matches in England, Ireland and Wales, Murray experienced an epiphany of thirst.</p><p>Drinking pints of Carlsberg, nectar out of British kegs and taps, in pubs with his teammates turned him into an aficionado of Liverpool Football Club because the brewery sponsored the Reds’ uniforms. They’ve become an obsession.</p><p>Murray went to Anfield, Liverpool’s hallowed grounds, two years ago for the last home match of Jürgen Klopp’s career. He returned a year ago, when Arne Slot capped his first season as Reds gaffer with a Premier League trophy.</p><p>He has hotel arrangements in Budapest and Madrid, sites for the next two Champions League finales, should Liverpool advance that far.</p><p>“Dude,” Murray said, “I’m a planner.”</p><p>He will relish this summer’s World Cup with special zeal because the previous tournaments were in Qatar (during the fall), Russia, Brazil and South Africa.</p><p>“Not just having a World Cup, but a World Cup in this time zone will be huge, very significant for every sportsbook,” Murray said. “Hopefully, the U.S. can make a run.”</p><h3>Super roar</h3><p>The Super Bowl, however, is Murray’s favorite event. Two weeks of buildup, big bets and exotic wagers, then whoosh, Super Sunday seems to fly by in several heartbeats.</p><p>With the rest of the city’s books at Seattle -4½ for Super Bowl LX, Murray and his team made it Seattle -5, at -108 (or risk $108 to win $100), to lure New England cash.</p><p>By midweek it hadn’t happened, as 75% of the money and two-thirds of the tickets were on the Seahawks. But the SuperBook sliced its price to -105 for the weekend, so perhaps Pats supporters were waiting.</p><p>“Not exactly a bad plan,” Murray said.</p><p>A year ago, a colleague sat with him in his office to watch the Eagles trounce the Chiefs 40-22 when late Kansas City points chewed into profits.</p><p>New England was 18-0 entering Super Bowl XLII, Murray’s first writing tickets. With 35 seconds left, Giants quarterback Eli Manning threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Plaxico Burress to give the underdog Giants a 17-14 triumph.</p><p>“It’s still the loudest I’ve ever heard this book,” Murray said. “There have been a lot of big moments, big events and plays here, but I’ve never heard a roar like that one.”<br></p>

entries.title: Fewer Americans are full-on MAGA than Trump thinks
entries.summary: <p>As we survey the wreckage of Donald Trump's second term, it is often said that <i>half the country voted for this</i>, or worse, <i>half the country is fine with this</i>. That isn't true.</p><p>MAGA is a bit of a moving target, but a recent Economist/YouGov <a class="Link" href="https://d3nkl3psvxxpe9.cloudfront.net/documents/econTabReport_8FWGyNz.pdf" target="_blank" >poll </a>found that only 24% of all voters described themselves as "MAGA supporters" and a perhaps surprisingly low 54% of Trump voters so identified. In other words, a minority of the voting public and only a little over half of the GOP is Trump's loyal base.</p><p>A <a class="Link" href="https://beyondmaga.us/media/ot0no1ro/beyondmaga_desktop_011926.pdf" target="_blank" >new survey</a> from More in Common, an international pro-democracy organization (I sit on its global board), offers a more granular look at Trump 2024 voters and provides further evidence that MAGA is definitely not half the country. They canvassed over 18,000 Americans over eight months. In looking over their findings, the group categorized the Trump voters into four clusters: MAGA hardliners, anti-woke conservatives, mainline Republicans and the reluctant right. Their conclusion? Trump voters were a coalition, not a cult.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-7f0000" name="module-7f0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p><b>MAGA hardliners:</b> These are the people we usually picture sporting red hats. They are highly religious, 91% white, mostly over 45 and less educated than other Trump voters — only 24% hold a college degree or higher compared with 29% of total Trump voters. They have little trust in institutions, believe that a sinister cabal runs media, business and politics, and are not averse to their leader ignoring the Supreme Court or other constitutional checks to "get things done."</p><p>A lamentable majority (60%) of the hardliners say their man should serve a third term. (In case you're wondering, yes, they do know the Constitution imposes a two-term limit, because it was included in the question.) Nearly three-quarters think we should "use our military to round up everyone who came to the U.S. illegally, put them in mass detention camps, and deport them." Seventy-four percent say voting for Trump is part of "living out my faith," and 94% (75% strongly) believe that God intervened to save Trump's life in Butler, Pennsylvania, so that he could make America great again.</p><p>This crowd cannot be trusted with power. They are conspiratorial, cultish, dismissive of constitutional limits and punitive toward their perceived political enemies. There isn't much good to say about them except this: They represent only 29% of Trump 2024 voters.</p><p><b>Anti-woke conservatives:</b> This next group is a little different. Among Trump voters, they are the least likely to say their faith determines their votes (14% versus an average of 27% among all Trump voters), but also the most hostile to Democrats. This is an alienated bunch who believe (91%) that wokeness is a very serious problem plaguing America. So, while that was enough to put them in the GOP column, only 33% agree that Trump should punish his opponents. This group represents 21% of Trump's coalition.</p><p><b>Mainline Republicans:</b> Making up some 30% of the coalition, these are the most likely to say that they are Trump supporters and Republicans equally, the least likely to say America is in decline (39% versus 58% of all Trump voters) and somewhat cool (43%) to ignoring court orders. Fifty-four percent of this group, compared with 76% of all Trump voters, agree with the statement "The woke left has ruined American education, news, and entertainment."</p><p><b>Reluctant right:</b> Of this final cohort, only a scant majority even identifies as Republican, and they were the most likely to say they voted for Trump, because he seemed "less bad" than Kamala Harris. This group, which represented 1 in 5 Trump voters, was the most likely to say they were ashamed of what happened on Jan. 6. Only 28% of this group favored rounding up undocumented immigrants and deporting them (compared with 52% of all Trump voters). Twenty-five percent of the reluctant right say they have doubts about or regret their vote entirely. That's a start.</p><p>The hardline MAGA group believes all of the worst things, but it's worth noting that some of the policies associated with Trump 2.0 have far less support among the rest of the coalition. Only 31% support deporting immigrants to third countries.</p><p>The Economist/YouGov poll found further fissures, suggesting that Trump voters are not a monolith. Asked whether they supported increases or decreases in spending on Medicaid, for example, which the GOP cut by $1 trillion in last year's "Big Beautiful Bill," only 28% of Trump voters favored decreasing spending.</p><p>Trump's base is hate-filled and dangerous, but it is not the majority. Nor is it half of the country. As a January <a class="Link" href="https://www.pewresearch.org/politics/2026/01/29/confidence-in-trump-dips-and-fewer-now-say-they-support-his-policies-and-plans/" target="_blank" >Pew poll </a>found, only 27% of respondents say they support all or most of Trump's policies, down from 35 % when he took the oath of office. Nearly all of that decline is attributable to Republicans. The erosion is proceeding fast, and based on the small size of the cult, there is plenty of room for more. Onward!</p><p><i>Mona Charen is policy editor of The Bulwark and host of the “Beg to Differ” podcast.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-510000" name="module-510000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: Build on vacant land in Black neighborhoods to stop exodus of Chicagoans
entries.summary: <p>I was stunned when I first saw the number: 702,617.</p><p>I stared at it for several seconds, as if it might change the longer I looked.</p><p>Was this real? Could it be this low, this fast?</p><p>It was only an estimate. But the non-Hispanic Black population for Chicago was just over 700,000, according to the U.S. Census Bureau’s <a class="Link" href="https://data.census.gov/table/ACSDT1Y2024.B03002?q=B03002:+Hispanic+or+Latino+Origin+by+Race&g=160XX00US1714000" target="_blank" ><u>2024 American Community Survey</u></a>. And, if you consider the margin of error — plus or minus 18,589 — Chicago’s Black population could be anywhere from about 721,000 to 684,000.</p><p>I’ve been researching and writing about Chicago’s Black population loss for several years, so I wasn’t shocked to see that the trend is continuing. But there was something about seeing that figure so close to sinking below 700,000 that shook me.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-8f0000" name="module-8f0000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnist </div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Columnist</div> </div><p>In 1980, the city’s Black population reached its peak at just under 1.2 million.</p><p>That means Chicago is on the verge of having seen its Black population plummet by half a million in a span of less than 50 years — essentially, more than 10,000 Black folks every year.</p><p>No other American city can make that claim.</p><p>The intractable problems that have contributed to the decline seem insurmountable.</p><p>The oasis of jobs that attracted millions of African Americans from the South, during the first and second waves of the Great Migration, to cities like Chicago, Cleveland, Detroit, Los Angeles, New York City and Philadelphia has long since dried up. In Chicago, deindustrialization’s greatest losses were witnessed on the city’s South and West sides. Manufacturing had been a stable source of employment for Black Chicago. No other industry has replaced the jobs and steady wages that went away once the factories closed. </p><p>The result: Chicago's Black unemployment rate was 14.5% in 2024, census data shows, the highest among the nation's largest cities.</p><p>Even after court rulings were issued to end restrictive covenants, and federal laws were passed to end housing discrimination, inequities and injustices remain. White flight, bank loan denials and other forms of disinvestment continue to take money out of the pockets of Black residents by diminishing their property values. Meanwhile, predatory lending, red light and speed camera tickets and disproportionate property taxes suck up much of what’s left.</p><p>The result: median Black wealth in Chicago is $0.</p><p>The list goes on and on.</p><p>But we’re not completely powerless to invigorate growth and development in Black Chicago.</p><p>There are some things over which we have much more control.</p><p>We can start by building or creating more places to live in Chicago’s Black spaces. We haven’t done a good job thus far of maintaining the housing stock in Black neighborhoods. For instance, majority-Black census tracts were the only spaces in Chicago to witness an overall decline in housing units between 2000 and 2020, according to my analysis of census data. In addition, those Black areas saw a decline in occupied housing units and an increase in vacant units during that span.</p><p>But there are ways we can do better.</p><p>Chicago’s city-owned land inventory includes nearly 13,000 properties that are already owned by the city. Nearly two-thirds of those properties are located in Black communities, which have, collectively, seen a decline of more than 90,000 Black residents over the past decade, my analysis shows.</p><p>In addition, the city gets at least 5,000 reports of vacant or abandoned buildings every year. Since 2019, the largest number of complaints have been for buildings in Roseland, West Englewood, Englewood, West Pullman, Austin, Greater Grand Crossing and Auburn Gresham. Those communities were all ranked among the top 10 for Black population loss over the past decade, according to my analysis. Collectively, those communities lost more than 60,000 Black residents.</p><p>Years ago, in a previous job, I had a chance to sit in on a meeting with planning and development officials from Chicago, San Francisco and New York City. They were exchanging ideas, challenges and best practices. After the Chicagoans droned on about how tough it was to create housing and development opportunities here, their out-of-town colleagues expressed jealousy. They marveled at all the available land in Chicago on which to build and create.</p><p>Where we saw shortcomings, they saw opportunities.</p><p>We can slow — and maybe even reverse — the city’s loss of its Black communities.</p><p>We have the land. We have the vacant property. Now, we just need the will.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/authors/alden-loury" target="_blank" ><i>Alden Loury</i></a><i> is data projects editor for WBEZ and writes a column for the Sun-Times.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-ab0000" name="module-ab0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>

entries.title: Civic Federation scapegoats city workers
entries.summary: <p>The Civic Federation — a mouthpiece for Chicago’s biggest corporations — is woefully out of touch in continuing to scapegoat Chicago’s workforce in its criticism of the 2026 city budget.</p><p>Specifically, the Sun-Times' Fran Spielman reports the group and those who hide behind its cloak wish that city workers were forced to take unpaid furlough days or were simply laid off ("<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2026/01/26/civic-federation-chicago-alternative-budget-opposition-aldermen-report" target="_blank" >Civic Federation pokes holes in Chicago’s alternative budget</a>" — Jan. 27). Anything less, they claim, "places the burden entirely on taxpayers, leaving labor completely off the hook." That’s a tired narrative by an organization that undermines its own credibility every time it targets workers.</p><p>Newsflash: City workers, who by law must live in Chicago, pay taxes just like every other Chicagoan. We’re the city that works only because of the dedication of those who keep it running every day. City residents want emergency responders, firefighters, police officers, librarians, snowplow drivers, garbage collectors, 311 operators and public health workers on the job to provide the essential services they rely on, not on furlough or in the unemployment line.</p><p>Yet the Civic Federation continues with its rhetoric that lacks facts and honesty. City workers are already doing more with less: Since 2019, the city’s payroll has shrunk by more than 500 employees. Contrary to claims made in the Sun-Times article, this budget did eliminate vacant positions and grant-funded jobs in human services and public health.</p><p>For our part, unions representing city workers have repeatedly suggested efficiencies that could save money without harming services, such as reducing the top-heavy ranks of management employees. And through the joint Labor Management Cooperation Committee, we regularly evaluate options to contain the city’s health care costs without reducing benefits.</p><p>The Civic Federation is a leading voice in the coalition of "no" when it comes to revenue-raising ideas. It’s time the organization contributes something substantive to the conversation around the future of our city instead of trotting out the same shallow talking points against workers.</p><p><i>Bob Reiter, president, Chicago Federation of Labor</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-a00000" name="module-a00000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>Give us your take</h3><br>Send letters to the editor to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. To be considered for publication, letters must include your full name, your neighborhood or hometown and a phone number for verification purposes. Letters should be a maximum of approximately 375 words.</div> </div><p></p><h3>Grant clawbacks leave community groups scrambling</h3><p>The People for Community Recovery has fought for years to protect and revitalize the historic "C Building" in Altgeld Gardens, to ensure it could be used for community good and not discarded.</p><p>The plan was to rehabilitate the building into the <a class="Link" href="https://www.peopleforcommunityrecovery.org/hazel-m-johnson-institute-for-environmental-justice" target="_blank" >Hazel M. Johnson Institute for Sustainability and Environmental Justice</a>: a high-efficiency, all-electric, sustainably powered hub for learning and research. It would be named for the group’s founder, who is considered the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/environment/2025/03/07/hazel-johnson-environmental-justice-chicago-trump-epa-cheryl-johnson-altgeld-gardens" >mother of the environmental justice movement</a>.</p><p>It would host workforce development and training, youth programming, offices for local organizations and community meeting space. It would be a community anchor — an engine for health, opportunity and local power.</p><p>People for Community Recovery applied for an Environmental Protection Agency<a class="Link" href="https://urldefense.com/v3/__https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/dfe6854c5ec740f59ec02bd3ae80e22c__;!!NO21cQ!HS0JFvO_Ey7MlXBRELSBYaphJLEuW8GdNdQtQwhq1-IwPqMFnq5zo-HHniB_CpUGsV82uMHwym6yTg$" target="_blank" > Community Change Grant</a> that would have made this vision real. This program was designed around a simple, overdue premise: communities closest to harm should be closest to the solutions, and they should have the resources to lead.</p><p>Then the Trump administration clawed back almost <a class="Link" href="https://insideclimatenews.org/news/17092025/trump-stops-29-billion-in-grants-for-environment-climate-renewable-energy/" target="_blank" >$29 billion </a>from communities for environmental health and climate projects like the Community Change grant, abruptly, with no meaningful explanation. Our application was left in limbo when the administration halted the grant program and funding.</p><p>The immediate impact is obvious. Our project is now forced into a scramble to look for funding elsewhere. But the deeper impact is harder to quantify and more dangerous. This kind of action shatters public trust.</p><p>When a community-based organization wins a grant, it is months and years of work, building partnerships, meeting requirements, crafting a project plan, aligning contractors and engaging residents. This is the work Chicago and other communities performed to secure grants that were abruptly rescinded.</p><p>And it is not just happening in Chicago. We are seeing grant clawbacks and funding freezes across the country. When commitments are revoked, the damage spreads. It delays projects. It drains capacity. It chills future participation.</p><p>If leaders want a solution, here it is: fund community-led investments and keep your word.</p><p>The clawbacks do real harm and cause long-term mistrust in partnering with government. They take away once-in-a-generation opportunities to turn environmental sacrifice zones into healthy, thriving neighborhoods. The path forward is not complicated. The EPA must keep its promise, protect awarded grants and invest in the solutions communities have already built.</p><p><i>Cheryl Johnson, executive director, People for Community Recovery</i><br><i>Melissa Lin Perrella, chief equity and justice officer, Natural Resources Defense Council</i></p><h3>Outraged over Epstein files </h3><p>Call me old-fashioned, but I remember a time when if the news came out that you were allegedly having sex with minors or palling around with someone who did, it would ruin your life.</p><p>More Epstein files have dropped. More proof that the president, along with <a class="Link" href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/epstein-lawyer-alan-dershowitz-makes-bonkers-excuse-when-cornered-on-role/" target="_blank" >Alan Dershowitz</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/bill-gates-elon-musk-epstein-files-what-documents-show/" target="_blank" >Bill Gates, Jeff Bezos, and Bill Clinton</a> were OK with what was taking place. The Department of Justice just dumped millions of pages of documents, videos and images from the Epstein investigation — the largest disclosure under the new Epstein Files Transparency Act. Donald Trump's name appears<a class="Link" href="https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/31/politics/new-documents-trump-epstein" target="_blank" > hundreds, by some counts even thousands</a>, of times. Even <a class="Link" href="https://variety.com/2026/film/news/jay-z-harvey-weinstein-pusha-t-epstein-files-1236647297/" target="_blank" >rapper</a>s Jay-Z and Pusha T are mentioned alongside <a class="Link" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2026/jan/30/elon-musk-epstein-files-island-visits" target="_blank" >Elon Musk</a>.</p><p>What these documents — released by our government — allege is the stuff of conspiracy websites, and yet, here we are.</p><p>There used to be a social contract. A rickety, duct-taped one, sure, but a real one. If you were exposed as someone who exploited kids, you were a goner. You didn't spin it. You didn't lawyer your way out of it. Your career was over, your name became radioactive, and the country agreed that some lines could not be crossed. Now, these false prophets of prosperity remain bulletproof, even if the sitting president is accused of horrific stuff.</p><p>The DOJ says the material does <a class="Link" href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2026/feb/01/epstein-files-todd-blanche-deputy-ag" target="_blank" >not provide grounds for new charges</a>. Trump and his allies have pushed back against how the material has been interpreted and reported, at times threatening litigation, while the DOJ maintains that some public claims lack credibility even as it confirms it will not pursue further charges.</p><p>And nothing is happening.</p><p>It's not even headline news. It's a side note against Iran, Greenland, tariffs, Venezuela, Israel and Ukraine. All by design, while a cabal of elites keeps it business as usual. Republicans stay on brand with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids. Liberals are spineless, masters of the performative.</p><p>To be clear, a name appearing in documents is not the same thing as being accused of a crime or a conviction. But when the name of a sitting president appears again and again in files tied to the most notorious sex-trafficking operation of our lifetime, the correct response is not a shrug. If it were baseless, demand a full, transparent investigation. Think that would ever happen on Trump's watch?</p><p>Where are the Democrats? Where are the Republicans who clamored for these files when it was about Bill Clinton?</p><p>Subpoena power. Independent prosecutors. Criminal referrals that aren't DOJ puppet strings. Anything short of that isn't justice, it's performative theater. And we're exhausted watching this horror show.</p><p><i>Robert Dean, Austin, Texas</i></p><h3>Hard pass on school vouchers</h3><p>Gov. JB Pritzker should opt Illinois out of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/01/28/pritzker-still-deciding-if-illinois-will-join-federal-program-that-funds-private-school-scholarships" >Donald Trump’s voucher program</a> tucked in his "One Big Beautiful Bill Act."</p><p>Public education is an invaluable institution under federal attack. This federal school voucher program, like the dismantling of the Department of Education and massive federal funding cuts, is designed to weaken a key component of American democracy.</p><p>For many generations, our taxpayer dollars have supported public schools that are open to all children and are the backbone of communities and civic life.</p><p>Private schools pick their students and operate without public transparency or accountability. When students leave a public school, the public school loses per student federal and state funding, but still must cover fixed costs.</p><p>Our governor should focus on supporting the quality of our wonderful lllinois public schools that today educate the vast majority of K-12 students. Public schools provide curriculum and services that respect all children's backgrounds and respond to individual families' needs and aspirations.</p><p>We should not open our state to an untested new federal tax credit that could funnel billions of public dollars nationwide not only to private religious schools and home schools, but also to services providers seeking profits without guardrails.</p><p>Focus on our children and the quality of their education, not the adults who are jockeying to pocket the tax credit dollars. This voucher program does not serve children well.</p><p><i>Ann Courter, former Oak Park Elementary District 97 school board president, Oak Park</i></p><h3>Dying art </h3><p>President Donald Trump announced he is closing the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for <a class="Link" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/2026/02/02/trump-kennedy-center-shutdown/" target="_blank" >two years</a>. Three years may be more practical as his presidency will have finished, and he will be able to devote more time to his love of the arts.</p><p>Apparently, the center needs a major update, so it can reach the standard required to have the Trump name attached. The timing may be advantageous, as it is now almost empty and rarely used.</p><p>The same logic could be applied to most film theaters, as a quick examination of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2026/01/31/chicago-draws-small-but-complimentary-audience-for-critically-panned-melania" >sales</a> in many regions and <a class="Link" href="https://www.thedailybeast.com/katie-miller-makes-bonkers-new-bid-to-prop-up-melania/" target="_blank" >bulk ticket buying</a> allegations tied to the "Melania" documentary indicate they are close to empty rarely used.</p><p><i>Dennis Fitzgerald, Melbourne, Australia</i></p><h3>Celebrate disabled community </h3><p>As we approach Valentine’s Day, a season often focused on romantic love, our community in Maywood is preparing for a different kind of celebration — one centered on the inherent dignity and value of every human life.</p><p>On Friday, Feb. 13, my church, <a class="Link" href="https://www.launchingpadww.net/" target="_blank" >The Launching Pad Worldwide</a>, and the nonprofit <a class="Link" href="https://www.west40.org/" target="_blank" >West40</a> will join hundreds of organizations globally to host "Night to Shine," a prom night for people with disabilities. Sponsored by the <a class="Link" href="https://timtebowfoundation.org/" target="_blank" >Tim Tebow Foundation</a>, this event, at West40's Intermediate Service Center in Maywood, is more than just a dance; it is a statement.</p><p>For too long, the disabled community has been overlooked or pushed to the margins. "Night to Shine" flips that narrative. When our 130-plus guests walk the red carpet to the sound of cheering crowds, they won't just be attendees — they are and will be kings and queens. In a world that often defines value by productivity or perfection, this night reminds us that every individual is an image-bearer of God, deserving of celebration, honor and royal treatment.</p><p>We invite Proviso Township and others to join us in this mission of inclusion. Whether through volunteering or simply shifting how we view our neighbors with special needs, let’s make sure the light from this one night shines throughout the entire year.</p><p><i>Thomas Clark, pastor, The Launching Pad Worldwide</i></p><h3>Can’t scare off corporations, rich folk</h3><p>Regarding millionaire and corporate tax proposals, I am not a millionaire. I am a middle-class resident living on the Northwest Side. Wealthy residents and corporations should pay their fair share of taxes. However, it's another thing to punish them. This will ultimately lead the wealthy and corporations to leave Chicago and Illinois. They will take with them their money and their jobs.</p><p><i>John Petersen, Belmont Heights</i></p><h3>CPS students: Protest on own time — not class time </h3><p>Chicago Public Schools students should not be allowed to miss school to protest anything. CPS students have some of the lowest test scores while Chicago has the highest taxes in the nation, all while the Chicago Teachers Union wants pay raises. </p><p>It’s great that the students want to <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/02/02/hundreds-of-cps-students-walk-out-of-school-to-protest-trumps-deportation-campaign" >stand for something</a> and be heard, but not while the hardworking citizens of Illinois are burdened by ever-increasing property taxes that are linked directly to CPS. Teachers and principals should keep their political views out of the classroom, and any who allow or encourage students to skip class should be held accountable. </p><p><i>Joe Ferro, Garfield Ridge</i><br></p>

entries.title: Dear Abby: Generous favor is rewarded with lies and abuse
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> I have grown children, grandchildren and a great-grandchild. I don't know if they think I am senile, but they seem to think I must cater to their every whim. Most of them are self-centered, thinking only of themselves. They borrow money from me, and sometimes I let them know it is a loan. Other times I give it to them and tell them that it is a gift. Loans are to be paid back. When it's given to you, it's yours.</p><p>One daughter, "Marie," borrowed a large sum of money and agreed to repay it in installments. She paid me back a portion of the money I had loaned her. When the next installment was due, she claimed her first payment was three times more than it had been. When I called her on it, she insisted she had given the higher amount.</p><p>I love all my family, but I don't intend for anyone to play me. Marie has given me no further payments, and the borrowing has stopped. When Marie tried to get in my face and talk down to me, my wife of 30 years let her know she wasn't to talk to me that way.</p><p>Since then, Marie has stopped speaking to us and has accused my wife of blocking her email, calls and texts. (That did not happen; I blocked them.) I just cannot see how a grown child could treat her parents the way we have been treated. I am deeply hurt, and I cannot seem to get past it. Your thoughts? — <i>OLD MAN IN THE MOUNTAINS</i></p><p><b>DEAR OLD MAN:</b> Your hurt is understandable. Not only is your self-entitled daughter a deadbeat, but she's also disrespectful. You treated her with kindness, and not only did she not repay the money you loaned her, but she attacked you verbally. I hope your other offspring have more character. That said, I don't think blocking Marie's ability to contact you was a wise decision. She may wish to apologize in the future, and you have been preventing that possibility.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My wife of 10 years has asked for a separation. She is set on divorce. She feels that, during the last four years since we had kids (2 and 4 years old), I have "chipped away at her self-esteem and self-worth."</p><p>During the past two months since our initial conversation, I have started seeing a therapist, gone on antidepressants and joined an empathy group session for men. I now see the hurt and pain I caused due to my untreated depression and negative self-image, and I have committed to change and save our marriage.</p><p>I stood by her and supported her through a major depression episode a year ago, and now she wants out. I am still in love with her, but she says that while she'll always love me, she is no longer IN love with me. I'm working on giving her space to heal. What else can I do? — <i>DISAPPOINTED HUSBAND IN MAINE</i></p><p><b>DEAR HUSBAND:</b> Ask your wife if she would agree to couples counseling with a licensed marriage and family therapist. Remind her that there are children involved, and even if the counseling isn't successful in healing your marriage, it could benefit all of you in the divorce process and beyond. Whether it will result in you and your wife reuniting is anyone's guess, but it may improve your relationship later.</p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>Abby shares more than 100 of her favorite recipes in two booklets: "Abby's Favorite Recipes" and "More Favorite Recipes by Dear Abby." Send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $16 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Cookbooklet Set, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>

entries.title: Happy times at Lush Wine & Spirits, if not for tariff uncertainty
entries.summary: <div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-df0000" name="module-df0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><b><i>Editor’s Note: </i></b><i>Last year, a new presidential administration stepped in with plans to disrupt the way companies do business through new policies, an effort to spur growth.</i><br><br><i>To help gauge the administration’s impact, the Chicago Sun-Times reached out to 10 Chicago area businesses in January 2025 and shared their plans and concerns for the future.</i><br><br><i>We’re now circling back, 12 months later, to see how they’ve fared.</i></div> </div><p>When President Donald Trump moved back into the White House in January 2025, one of Mitch Einhorn's biggest worries was increased tariffs.</p><p>A year later, the co-owner of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2025/01/31/tariffs-labor-property-taxes-swirl-around-lush-wine-spirits" >Lush Wine & Spirits</a> said tariffs are still top of mind.</p><p>Since 2005, Lush has positioned itself as a friendly, accessible wine shop paired with a cozy bistro, with locations in Roscoe Village and West Town. Customers can buy a bottle and uncork it in the restaurant, or they can try a glass with dinner and buy a bottle to take home.</p><p>Menu items range from imported caviar service to sandwiches and seafood. Brunch items include avocado fried egg toast, Georgian cheese bread and brioche French toast.</p><p>With so many imported items, the business is especially vulnerable to the rapid-fire tariffs Trump has announced, then often pulled back, throughout the first year of his second term.</p><p>"It's just so arbitrary," said Einhorn, 63.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d50000" name="module-d50000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h4>Lush Wine & Spirits</h4><b>About:</b> Boutique wine and spirit store, as well as restaurant and wine bar<br><br><b>Neighborhood:</b> Roscoe Village and West Town<br><b>Owners:</b> Mitch and Cliff Einhorn<br><b>Founded:</b> 2005<br><b>Staff size:</b> 15<br><b>Estimated annual sales:</b> More than $1 million</div> </div><p>Since August, U.S. importers of European wines have been paying 15% tariffs. The taxes are typically passed down to consumers in the form of higher prices.</p><p>Last month, Trump threatened 10% tariffs — rising to 25% by June — on products from eight European countries unless the U.S. was allowed to purchase Greenland. Shortly after, he threatened 200% tariffs on French wine and Champagne after French President Emmanuel Macron snubbed an invitation to join Trump's new Board of Peace, composed of a group of world leaders, who can pay a $1 billion admission fee for a lifetime membership, with Trump as chairman for as long as he likes.</p><p>The wildly fluctuating tariffs were heartburn-inducing for Einhorn, who said he had orders in transit from France when the 200% tariff was suggested.</p><p>Within a week, Trump backed off on Greenland-related threats and has stopped mentioning 200% tariffs on French imports. But Einhorn said the unpredictability is harmful. He decided to pause further purchases until things settle down.</p><p>He also worries about people whose livelihoods are connected to imports, such as port workers, truckers and retail entries.title: Lily Fisher shows she's 'one of the best players in the state' as Libertyville knocks off Maine South
entries.summary: <p>The fourth quarter belonged to Libertyville junior guard Lily Fisher.</p><p></p><p>Spanning back to the third quarter, Maine South had started to gain traction against the Wildcats. The Hawks were on a 5-0 run when Fisher calmly dribbled down the court, got around her defender and drilled a pull-up three-pointer.</p><p></p><p>After getting a defensive stop, Fisher then assisted on junior forward Elle Knight’s basket to swing momentum back in Libertyville's favor. Fisher finished with 10 points in the quarter and was huge in Libertyville’s 59-49 win over Maine South.</p><p></p><p>“She's definitely the best player in Lake County,” coach Greg Pederson said. “And I think she's shown, as we move around a little bit, that she's one of the best players in the state.”</p><p></p><p>Fisher finished with 23 points and 14 rebounds. Libertyville (22-5) ran a lot of its offense through Fisher. Whenever she has the ball, the defense is loaded up to take her out of a rhythm. But she’s difficult to guard because of her patience, improved shooting ability and passing vision. She dissected Maine South’s defense out of the pick-and-roll, regularly finding her teammates for baskets.</p><p></p><p>At 6-1, Fisher is a physical guard. She relished getting into the paint to finish through contact. When Maine South cut the lead to four in the fourth quarter, Fisher drove to the basket and absorbed contact to get to the line.</p><p></p><p>Though she scored just five points in the second quarter, Fisher's impact was profoundly felt in the second quarter. She was critical in finding her teammates for open shots and layups. Knight is adept at setting screens, and Libertyville has made it an emphasis to surround Fisher with shooters to open up driving lanes or make teams pay for loading up on her drives.</p><p></p><p>“Lily gets me open a lot,” said senior guard Ella Pawelczy, who scored 11 points and knocked down three threes. “That's like the biggest aspect of my game.”</p><p></p><p>Pawelczy hit two big threes in the third quarter when Maine South was mounting a comeback to keep them at bay. For Pawelczy, Saturday’s win showed the growth that Libertyville has undergone over the course of the season. In an earlier matchup against Maine South, Libertyville lost 46-28 — Fisher said that they got “whooped.” Pawelczy said that the team was focused coming into today’s game and wanted to start the game strong. As the senior leader, she sets the tone.</p><p></p><p>“She's our team leader,” Pederson said. “She's had days where she's missed her first three and we tell her. ‘Keep shooting,’ and she has no problem taking that request because she'll keep shooting. She played like a senior today.”</p><p>Knight finished with eight points and eight rebounds. Freshman guard Addie Casey finished with four points and five rebounds. Limiting Maine South to one shot on each possession was vital.</p><p></p><p>“We struggle with [rebounding], and they like to get second-chance points a lot, so I feel like we got them off the boards and that caused us to get more possessions,” Fisher said.</p><p></p><p>The Wildcats have three games remaining in the regular season, two of which are against formidable teams in Glenbrook South and Carmel. Saturday’s win was a validation of the growth they’ve shown this season.</p><p></p><p>“We’re gonna have so much confidence going into the playoffs,” Pawelczy said. “We're excited with our seed for sectionals, and we're excited. This win is going to be so important for us, especially for some girls who are newer to the team and to the playoffs.”<br></p>

entries.title: ¿Quieres festejar al estilo Chicago-Rican? Te decimos dónde ver el show de medio tiempo del Super Bowl
entries.summary: <p>La superestrella puertorriqueña Bad Bunny está a punto de presentar el primer show de medio tiempo en español en la historia del Super Bowl.</p><p>Debido a la esperada actuación, que muchos están llamando el “Benito Bowl” (el nombre completo del artista es Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio), los habitantes de Chicago están planeando <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment-culture/2026/02/03/bad-bunnys-hottest-local-super-bowl-pregame-is-at-the-chicago-public-library" target="_blank" >fiestas previas</a> inspiradas en Puerto Rico y fiestas para ver el juego.</p><p>En el barrio puertorriqueño de Chicago, Humboldt Park, los organizadores de las anuales Fiestas Puertorriqueñas están organizando una <a class="Link" href="https://www.instagram.com/p/DTk9a1gDvM7/?igsh=Z2Q2eWV6a2o4eHl4" target="_blank" >fiesta que está agotada</a> en su espacio pop-up VIP Residencia en 2701 W. Division St.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-2e0000" name="module-2e0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>En <a class="Link" href="https://laylo.com/laylo-mjbadmr/Lacasita?utm_source=ig&utm_medium=social&utm_content=link_in_bio&fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAc3J0YwZhcHBfaWQMMjU2MjgxMDQwNTU4AAGnoRjYOFTFWWsgPJV5rb5dyHKM30b5WuJdHk6p0FTYIZutcnftNE5pnyBCjqY_aem_v0TxLitnCDnrMxBIzI30bw" target="_blank" >Galería Chicago</a>, las bebidas inspiradas en la isla estarán en el menú, y el equipo detrás de <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/food-drink/2025/12/19/parranda-bad-bunny-pop-up-puerto-rico-humboldt-park" target="_blank" >La Parranda Boricua</a> llevará su “casita” al HVAC Pub de Wrigleyville.</p><p>Aquí hay un vistazo rápido a las mejores fiestas locales para ver el Super Bowl con temática de Bad Bunny.</p><h2><b>Chicago </b></h2><h3><b>Bar Sol @ Navy Pier, 600 E. Grand Ave. </b></h3><p>¡Pachanga! Chicago es una serie mensual de cultura latina que generalmente se lleva a cabo en el Bar Sol de Navy Pier. Presentan artistas locales, DJs, clases de baile, mercados artesanales y más. Para el domingo del Super Bowl, DJ Barbi, DJ Marino y Memo Duarte proporcionarán la música, y las entradas incluyen alitas, pizza y aperitivos ilimitados hasta el medio tiempo. Si realmente solo vas por el show de medio tiempo, hay una sala de juegos para pasar el tiempo hasta que Benito suba al escenario.</p><p><b>Cuándo:</b> 5:30 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas:</b> $29.34+ </p><p><b>Info: </b><a class="Link" href="https://pachangachicago.com" target="_blank" >pachangachicago.com</a></p><p></p><h3><b>Chucherías Tropical Creations, 2627 W. Division St. </b></h3><p>Los pasteles puertorriqueños con un toque de Bad Bunny estarán en el menú para la fiesta del Super Bowl en esta panadería de Humboldt Park. Además de la proyección del partido entre los New England Patriots y los Seattle Seahawks, habrá mucha música y baile. Gracias a un patrocinio de Medalla Light, la cerveza favorita de Puerto Rico se servirá durante toda la noche.</p><p><b>Cuándo: </b>4 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas: </b><a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/benito-bowl-watch-party-registration-1980833110155?aff=erellivmlt" target="_blank" >Gratis con RSVP</a></p><p></p><h3><b>HVAC Pub, 3540 N. Clark St. </b></h3><p>El año pasado, los creadores de <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/food-drink/2025/12/19/parranda-bad-bunny-pop-up-puerto-rico-humboldt-park" target="_blank" >La Parranda Boricua</a> establecieron su negocio en la Galería Leo Lo Lai de Humboldt Park. Construyeron una réplica de la casita que Bad Bunny presentó en el escenario durante su residencia en Puerto Rico el verano pasado. Perfecta para fotos, la casita hace su debut en Wrigleyville para el Super Bowl en HVAC Pub.</p><p>Los invitados pueden disfrutar de música de DJs locales y beber <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/taste/2026/01/07/chicago-coquito-competition-brings-out-creativity-tradition-and-cultural-fusion" target="_blank" >coquito</a> tradicional puertorriqueño mientras el partido se transmite en varias televisores del lugar. HVAC también ofrecerá varias ofertas de comida y bebida para el día del juego y servicio de botella. No hay cover para entrar, pero se recomienda hacer <a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/benito-bowl-parranda-watch-party-tickets-1981960305627?aff=oddtdtcreator&utm_source=ig&utm_medium=social&utm_content=link_in_bio&fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAc3J0YwZhcHBfaWQMMjU2MjgxMDQwNTU4AAGnayy9pNy-t6URMWeB8dKwdF4baqIkkoO0BFVxfvrks4ZLficfSBrFFnEnbVM_aem_9WexVshkK5LujVLmv0ym_A" target="_blank" >RSVP</a>.</p><p><b>Cuándo:</b> 3 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas: </b><a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/benito-bowl-parranda-watch-party-tickets-1981960305627?aff=oddtdtcreator&utm_source=ig&utm_medium=social&utm_content=link_in_bio&fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAc3J0YwZhcHBfaWQMMjU2MjgxMDQwNTU4AAGnayy9pNy-t6URMWeB8dKwdF4baqIkkoO0BFVxfvrks4ZLficfSBrFFnEnbVM_aem_9WexVshkK5LujVLmv0ym_A" target="_blank" >Gratis con RSVP</a></p><p></p><h3><b>Galería Chicago, 9 W. Division St. </b></h3><p>La fiesta en este club nocturno en Old Town promete durar hasta las 4 a.m., con DJs locales tocando reggaetón antiguo y moderno. El evento también contará con cócteles inspirados en la isla y más en su pop-up La Casita, que también utiliza imágenes de la gira de Bad Bunny en 2025.</p><p><b>Cuándo:</b> 5 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas: </b><a class="Link" href="https://laylo.com/laylo-mjbadmr/Lacasita?utm_source=ig&utm_medium=social&utm_content=link_in_bio&fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAc3J0YwZhcHBfaWQMMjU2MjgxMDQwNTU4AAGnoRjYOFTFWWsgPJV5rb5dyHKM30b5WuJdHk6p0FTYIZutcnftNE5pnyBCjqY_aem_v0TxLitnCDnrMxBIzI30bw" target="_blank" >Gratis con RSVP</a></p><p></p><h3><b>Sentido 018, 4046 W. Armitage Ave. </b></h3><p>Otro experimento cultural en Chicago proviene de <a class="Link" href="https://www.instagram.com/sentido.wav/" target="_blank" >Sentido</a>, una serie de DJs conocida por apoderarse de los mejores establecimientos latinos de la ciudad, desde cafés y panaderías hasta museos y talleres de autos. Este domingo, tomarán el Centro Cultural Segundo Ruiz Belvis (SRBCC) en Hermosa con un alineamiento de DJs locales y muchas opciones de bebidas alcohólicas y no alcohólicas. En lugar de cobrar por las entradas, los organizadores de Sentido están alentando a los asistentes a donar al centro comunitario en el lugar. SRBCC es una de las instituciones latinas más antiguas y de más larga trayectoria en Chicago.</p><p><b>Cuándo: </b>5 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas: </b><a class="Link" href="https://partiful.com/e/rKrpsUO4xEPYbYGgixxL?source=share&utm_source=ig&utm_medium=social&utm_content=link_in_bio&fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAc3J0YwZhcHBfaWQMMjU2MjgxMDQwNTU4AAGnx2Wrl6FbIOQArw4pfOXJ-qmJRxqBT4zN6T_D4Xu0zPRjXP5gLqM813GORNU_aem_2ORbSIuA3EpqIUZl3chz1w" target="_blank" >Gratis con RSVP</a></p><hr><p></p><h2><b>Suburbios </b></h2><h3><b>Jardín GastroBar, 6431 Cermak Rd., Berwyn </b></h3><p>Este bar y restaurante que se especializa en mariscos en Berwyn también está organizando una fiesta para ver el Benito Bowl. Jardín GastroBar promete un surround sound para disfrutar óptimamente del show de medio tiempo, y su menú de comida estará disponible hasta la 1 a.m. La fiesta posterior contará con presentaciones de grupos locales de música regional mexicana, como Grupo Vanguardia y Los Preferidos. Las mujeres entran gratis antes de las 7 p.m.</p><p><b>Cuándo:</b> 5 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas: </b><a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/benito-bowl-super-bowl-watch-party-w-live-grupos-after-party-tickets-1982457818702?aff=erellivmlt" target="_blank" >Gratis con RSVP</a></p><p></p><h3><b>5 Stars Sports, 1150 27th Ave., Melrose Park </b></h3><p>Considerándose la “fiesta de visualización del Super Bowl Latinx más grande” en la zona, esta celebración se lleva a cabo dentro de una instalación deportiva en Melrose Park. La enorme fiesta contará con varias pantallas gigantes, DJs en vivo, juegos para el público, un toro mecánico, comida, bebidas y una after party. Además, el establecimiento ofrecerá servicio de transporte al lugar.</p><p><b>Cuándo: </b>3 p.m. el 8 de febrero</p><p><b>Entradas: </b><a class="Link" href="https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-largest-latinx-super-bowl-watch-party-after-party-no-cover-charge-tickets-1980778392493?aff=oddtdtcreator" target="_blank" >Gratis con RSVP</a></p><p></p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
